importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on October 20, 2025, marking the main festival day and serving as a key cultural and religious observance for over a billion people across South Asia and diaspora communities.
Sikhs commemorate Bandi Chhor Divas on October 21, 2025, marking the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings from imprisonment, a significant historical event in Sikh history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Diwali spans five days, from October 20 to October 25, 2025, forming a cultural and spiritual period of celebration, renewal, and communal gathering.

keyTakeAways: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is a major festival observed by Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists, symbolizing the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil.
The festival is celebrated globally, especially in India, Nepal, Malaysia, Fiji, and other countries with South Asian diasporas, reflecting its cultural significance beyond religious boundaries.
The five days of Diwali include Dhanteras, Choti Diwali (Naraka Chaturdashi), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja), Padwa (Govardhan Puja), and Bhai Dooj, each with unique rituals and traditions.

For Hindus, Diwali often marks the return of Rama and Sita from exile, or the defeat of demon king Ravana; for Sikhs, it is Bandi Chhor Divas, commemorating the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings from imprisonment.
For Jains, Diwali signifies the attainment of enlightenment by Lord Mahavira; for Buddhists, it marks Emperor Ashoka’s embrace of Buddhism.
The festival is not only religious but also cultural and economic, with people engaging in home cleaning, exchanging gifts, feasting, and opening new business accounts.
Gambling games like teen patti are traditionally played, rooted in a legend involving Shiva and Parvati.
Diwali marks the beginning of the new Hindu financial year, with businesses opening new accounting books.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, the festival of lights, is celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide on October 20, 2025. The festival symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil, with diverse religious narratives including the return of Rama and Sita, the defeat of demons like Ravana and Narakasura, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind by Sikhs. Celebrations include home lighting with diyas, fireworks, feasting, and gift-giving, with distinct traditions on each of the five days of Diwali. The holiday transcends religion, becoming a cultural and economic event, with the start of the new Hindu financial year and traditional games like teen patti. The article underscores Diwali’s deep cultural roots, global reach, and significance as a time of renewal, family, and community.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
